title: Typhoon Hagibis: Death toll rises in Japan as rescue operations continue
text:
At least seven people were killed and 15 were missing after a powerful typhoon blasted across Japan, bringing fierce winds, torrential rainfall, flooding and blackouts.

Tokyo was brought to standstill ahead of the arrival of Super Typhoon Hagibis, which made landfall at around 7pm on Saturday evening in Shizuoka Prefecture, just south of the capital.

More than six million people were advised to evacuate across central and eastern Japan, with record-breaking rainfall and gusts of wind of up to 134 mph triggering burst rivers, flooding and landslides.

The powerful storm continued northwards along the eastern coast – an area badly hit in the 2011 earthquake, tsunami and nuclear crisis – with officials reportedly monitoring irregular readings from sensors monitoring water at Fukushima nuclear Daiichi power plant.

As the capital awoke to blue post-storm skies on Sunday morning, 376,000 homes had no electricity and 14,000 lacked running water, according to government officials. With rescue efforts in full force across Japan, Yoshihide Suga, the chief government spokesman, confirmed there had been extensive damage to housing due to flooding.

Many rain and flood warnings were lifted, although rescue operations continued around the clock for those stranded or missing in flooded areas.
description: At least seven people were killed and 15 were missing after a powerful typhoon blasted across Japan, bringing fierce winds, torrential rainfall, flooding and blackouts.
